translated: and it is of three kinds as visible-data base, etc., that is to say, visible data as the visible-data base are visible and impingeable; the eleven kinds of derivative material, namely, the four beginning with colour , the four beginning with sex , and the seven beginning with sound , are invisible but impingeable; the remaining sixteen kinds of derivative material, namely, the four beginning with bodily intimation , the four beginning with the temperature-originated kinds of matter , the four beginning with nutriment-originated matter , and the four beginning with space-element-originated matter , are invisible and impingeable. That which is born of kamma is kamma-born; the eight faculties and the physical heart- basis are kamma-born; that which is born with other conditions than kamma is not kamma-born; that which is born neither from kamma nor with other conditions than kamma is neither kamma-born nor not kamma-born; that is, ageing and the impermanence of material instances. So it is of three kinds.

translated: and it is of three kinds as visible-data base, etc., that is to say, the visible-data base is visible and impingeable; the eleven kinds of materiality consisting of the ten sensitive-data and the sound-data are invisible and impingeable; the remaining sixteen kinds of materiality consisting of the subtle materiality are invisible and impingeable. It is of three kinds as born of kamma, etc., that is to say, the eight faculties and the physical heart- basis are born of kamma; the rest are not born of kamma; and ageing and dissolution are neither born of kamma nor not born of kamma. It is of three kinds as seen, heard, sensed, and cognized, etc., that is to say, the visible-data base is seen; the sound-data base is heard; the mind-consciousness element and the mental data base are sensed; the rest are cognized; and ageing and dissolution are neither seen nor heard nor sensed nor cognized. It is of three kinds as door and as physical basis, etc., that is to say, the eye-sensitivity, etc., are a door and a physical basis; the physical heart-basis is a physical basis only and not a door; the rest are neither a door nor a physical basis. It is of three kinds as door and as faculty, etc., that is to say, the eye-sensitivity, etc., are a door and a faculty; the ear-sensitivity, etc., are a door only and not a faculty; the physical-basis sensitivity is a faculty only and not a door; the rest are neither a door nor a faculty. It is of three kinds as physical basis and as faculty, etc., that is to say, the physical-basis sensitivity is a physical basis and a faculty; the eye-sensitivity, etc., are a faculty only and not a physical basis; the rest are neither a physical basis nor a faculty.

NibbÄna is the object of the path.

translated: If so, then why is there no destruction of the self, as there is of the consciousness, because of the non-separation of the self from the parts of the body, as there is of consciousness?ğŸ”½If there is no reason for the destruction of consciousness and not of the self, then, according to your theory, the self alone should be destroyed and not the consciousness.ğŸ”½If the self is not destroyed when the consciousness is destroyed, then the two are not non-separate. If that is so, what is the fault?ğŸ”½But you said that just as the self is different from the parts of the body, such as the form, feeling, etc., so also the consciousness is different from the parts of the consciousness.ğŸ”½This is a low opinion, because it is a theory of non-separation.ğŸ”½If, like the form, feeling, etc., the self is not destroyed when the parts of the self are destroyed, then, like the consciousness, the self is not destroyed when the consciousness is destroyed.

translated: and the self is not destroyed? If so, then why is it that the self is not destroyed when the consciousness is destroyed? If you say that there is no reason, then according to your theory the self itself should be destroyed, and the consciousness should remain. If you say that when the consciousness is destroyed the self is not destroyed, then the two are not the same. If that is so, what is the fault? But you said that just as the characteristics of visible form, odour, etc., are different from each other even though they occur in the same place, so too the characteristics of the self and consciousness are different from each other even though they occur in the same place. Your assertion is inferior. If, like visible form, odour, etc., the self does not perish even though the consciousness perishes, then you are at fault. If it is the opposite of what you have said, then let the self perish and let the consciousness remain.
